awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning/Transmission Electron Microscope for Materials Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Materials play an important role in the areas of biopharmaceuticals, medicine, the environment and energy storage.  The structure of materials at the nanoscale play an important role in how these materials behave at more macroscopic, physically relevant scales.  Thus, it is important to get high fidelity images of materials at the smallest possible scales. A state-of-the art scanning/transmission electron microscope (S/TEM), acquired through this grant, will enable visualization and chemical characterization of a broad variety of materials at the nanoscale.  This information will be used to understand material functionalities, as well as develop new materials for applications in diagnostics and targeted drug delivery, pollutant capture and batteries.  The instrument will serve several universities and industries through existing and new interactions. Dozens of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and undergraduates will be trained to use this cutting edge analytical tool, preparing them to contribute effectively to the fast-paced advances in materials science and engineering research.

The transmission electron microscope will be used to image (a) biocompatible polymer beads loaded with drugs and magnetic nanoparticles for combined therapeutics and diagnostics (b) silver nanoparticles exposed to bacteria to uncover the causes behind their biocidal properties (c) bioengineered proteins and cell surfaces, to get a fundamental understanding of protein function (d) evolving structures in lithium ion battery electrodes, to be able to design higher energy density batteries that are safe and long lasting (e) nanoparticle formation and evolution in solution, to further the design of softeners for hard water, and for consumer products. The S/TEM will be a key enabler for all of these projects.

This project is jointly funded by CBET-MRI Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
NSF MRI - Acquisition of a Scanning/Transmission Electron Microscope for Materials Research and Education ? NSF 1919588

A JEOL 200F 200 KV Scanning/Transmission Electron Microscope was purchased through this MRI award.  After significant delays caused by room modifcation requirements and supply chain delays, the microscope was installed and commissioned in April, 2022.  Beyond the high-resolution imaging and Energy Dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy, this instrument has a Gatan K3 Direct Electron Camera, a Gatan Continuum EELS detector and cryogenic capability. The direct electron camera removes the inefficiencies associated with an electron to photon conversion on a scintillation screen in typical electron microscopes. It allows imaging at extremely low electron doses, thus avoiding damage to beam sensitive samples. Structural biology colleague and co-PI Jodi Camberg is preparing proteins for imaging using the K3 camera.  The EELS capability has been exploited to obtain images of hot spots around plasmonic carbon-black templated gold nanoparticles recently fabricated in the Bose lab.  NanoSoft LLC, a local startup has used the instrument to image biological membranes and lipid vesicles.  The previous Operations Director and now Scientific Director of the facility Dr. Andreu, has complete training this new instrument. She will be spending time training the next set of users in the Spring semester.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2022
Modified by: Arijit Bose
